sentence: An Inspiring Movie: Hello Love Goodbye, despite being a largely feel-good film, did not shy away from the harsh realities that its OFW audience experiences
Despite being upfront with the struggles of an OFW, it still serves as a gentle, hopeful reminder for our modern day heroes to not forget to choose themselves
To not forget that they can allow themselves to dream, to love, and most of all, to be human
It show that love can wait but our dreams it knock once like opportunity grab it once it came in your or our life
Kathryn Bernardo portrays Joy's exhaustion, anger and resolution so potently without much words
It all comes out in the way her lids look heavy from a two-hour sleep; how her shoulders slump as she grapples with the thought of her agonizingly routine life
We see it in her quiet moments in the night when she can catch a few minutes just to stare blankly at the wall
The depiction felt authentic and tugs at your heartstrings, Joy is the symbol of women with dream
And also her leading man this is a more mature role for Alden as well, and the material lets him show a deeper side to his acting chops
His character's personal story carried as much weight as the romance, and in Ethan's vulnerable moments, we see Alden as a dramatic actor, and not just a tutti-frutti leading man
That's not to say that he didn't play the charismatic boyfriend role well, though
The kilig factor we as always cranked up to high, thanks also to his and Kathryn's organic chemistry
The most unforgettable scene in this movie when Ethan and Joy decided to leave each other to continue their dream and when Ethan said "will you give the rest of your time with me in Hong Kong

Those line make me sad and overwhelmed because even they know that they leave each other they choose to understand and make those little time to make memorable, they choose to spent those time to be happy
This movie make us inspired that life is like a photography, we developed from negative
Love is About Letting Go
Not Sacrifice: I've seen a few of Kathryn Bernardo's films, and I believe she turned in the performance of her life
She stepped away from the typical romantic-comedies (many of which are actually quite good), and challenged herself to take on the role of a much deeper and much more complex character in Joy
I have always marveled--and not in a good way--of how people tend to use others; even people they love; even members of their own families
Of course, children are usually guilted into it
In short, it's a parent's way of saying, "I suffered, and so now you must suffer too
Because it's how families work

"

As stated in other reviews, I am an ESL teacher
I've lived and worked in South Korea, China, and Taiwan
I know quite a bit about how Asian parents tend to treat their kids
You'll scarcely find parents who are more dedicated to teaching their children about discipline and hard-work
The large contrast between them and western parents, is that western parents tend to allow their kids to do whatever they want
They're spoiled beyond belief
What is needed is a balance
As the eldest daughter, Joy is in Hong Kong working several jobs in order to keep herself alive as well as sending money back home to her family in the Phillippines
She has a nursing degree
Her dream is to go to Canada to pursue what she loves

Of course, she meets and falls in love with Ethan, a young man who is also from the Phillippines, who is trying to support his family as well, after a disastrous relationship that nearly cost him everything
Ethan, of course, is hoping that Joy will decide to stay in Hong Kong, and not go to Canada
This is when the film really grabs the viewer to see what Joy will decide to do
Love is not about sacrifice for someone else
Sacrifice is about losing something, and love is never about loss
It's always about who you are
In all her wisdom, Joy has to explain this to Ethan as well as outlining the consequences of not pursuing her dream
Fortunately, Ethan finally gets it and is able to do what only love can do: let go
Some can do it
In the end, you can only truly look after yourself and not lose sight of your own dreams
If you forge ahead, then you have gained more profound wisdom about life than what most people can only dream about
My only complaint of the film was that the chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards was not what it should have been
I'd say it was pretty obvious that Kathryn Bernardo did not want to do any kissing scenes with Alden due to her love and respect for her boyfriend, Daniel Padilla
The only kiss we see is one on her forehead in the dark
I couldn't help but wonder how much more powerful the film would have been if another actress had performed in the role, or if Padilla himself hadn't turned the role down (which I read that he had)
Still, this is a memorable film that challenges everyone to go after their dreams and let nothing and no one stand in your way
What a nice surprise of a movie
: Right, well I didn't really know what I was getting into here when I sat down to watch the 2019 Tagalog movie that was filmed in Hong Kong
And given my fascination with Asian movie, of course I sat down to watch "Hello, Love, Goodbye"
And I must definitely say that writers Carmi Raymundo, Cathy Garcia-Molina and Ronalisa A
Co came up with a rather enthralling storyline; one that definitely provided as much of entertainment and enjoyment, as it was a movie that was very watchable and likeable
The storyline is one that easily sways away the audience, because it is wholehearted and nicely told storyline
And milling about in the storyline are some nicely detailed and interesting characters
So a big thumbs up to the writers on this accomplishment
I will say that the acting in the movie was good
Now, I am not overly familiar with Tagalog cinema, but my wife told me that there were some rather famous Tagalog actresses and actors in the movie
Nevertheless, I think the acting performances were spot on
At the same time, with providing a good story and good entertainment, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" really brought me back to my four years of living and working in Hong Kong
This movie stoked so many memories and definitely spurred a desire to return to Hong Kong to revisit that fabulous place
If you like romantic movies, then I strongly believe that the 2019 movie "Hello, Love, Goodbye" from director Cathy Garcia-Molina is a movie that you will thoroughly enjoy
I was more than genuinely entertained by this movie, and it is a movie that I can warmly recommend you sit down to watch
My rating of "Hello, Love, Goodbye" lands on a well-deserved seven out of ten stars
Hello, Love, no Goodbyes
: Being the highest-grossing Philippine movie thus far, I hope you don't mind if I came into watching this with high expectations

Still I was skeptic because the assumption was it will be another one of those formulaic Star Cinema movie starring Kathryn Bernardo, directed by Cathy Molina-Garcia, set in an international location, usual love story but with a twist: we get a new boy this time in the form of Alden Richards
For the most part I was right, it was all you could ever expect from the same group that gave us the highest-grossing movie the year before, 'How's of Us
' Amidst it's shortcomings, 'Hello, Love, Goodbye' is a pleasant surprise for a movie who's theme has been done a million times

Part of it's success can be attributed to showing us the reality of our hardworking domestic helpers in Hong Kong (which the OFW community all over the world related and responded to) and it did not give us the usual ending we are used to, which makes a sequel possible seeing as all three already expressed interest in doing
The story was well-written for the most part and my favorite was the start of the movie
It was a different approach, fast-paced and intriguing

While at some point it had to slow down to become what it really was meant to be in the first place, a typical Pinoy love story, at least it introduced something new to the audience that can be the new norm in the future
Acting-wise, Kathryn and Alden both delivered but both lacked maturity which I'm hoping can be improved on once the sequel rolls around
It took a while for their chemistry to kick in, possibly a result of being pigeonholed in their respective love teams for a long time
Kathryn can act, but she has certain mannerisms when she deliver some of her lines that breaks my concentration from her acting
I'm still getting rich girl even though she's supposed to be covered in filth from hiding under a pile of garbage bags
Alden still comes from the John Lloyd Cruz school for acting, but as soon as he develops his own signature he should be destined for greater things
The supporting cast did what was required of them, with Maxine Medina and Jameson Blake as highlights
There's always the burden of asking whether this is the movie that will propel Philippine cinema back to it's old glory
Obviously this is not it, but delightfully it's not a step back as well
Knowing this specific tandem and formula works, hopefully everyone involved will be more keen on wanting to elevate the viewing experience the second time around
I keep harping on this because I honestly believe it has the potential to become even more special than what they've already done here
Truly amazing: This is so far, the best Filipino movie of 2019
I really love the story, which shows a lot about the lives of Filipino workers in Hong Kong
This will make you laugh out loud a lot and cry hard
For me this is Cathy Garcia-Molina's best movie
Kathryn and Alden really shines in this, great acting by the whole cast
It also has great shots, cinematography and soundtrack so it is a must watch
Mature and bold love story: The two stars from the two different stations hit it off with good chemistry in this mature love story

Although the story is as typical as any Filipino love/romance movie could be, I like the fact that the writer and director went for the bold path of ending the movie with "goodbye", instead of coming up with an epilogue that let the two lovers meet again in some future
The two lead stars are engaging enough for you to care what happens to them in the end but there are some parts where it could drag
Still, I can understand the clamor when this movie came out in 2019
THE BEST FILIPINO MOVIE EVER: This is the best pinoy movie ever
The characters are superb
Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards performance was the best
There is no boring moments in the movie
It's a must watch for everyone
Kathryn Bernardo played the role of Joy a Filipino worker in Hong Kong who is struggling and doing odd jobs to take care of her family
On the other hand Alden Richards played the role of Ethan a funny and unserious bartender who later crossed path with Joy and the story of their undying love begins
The story is not just another pinoy love story
It's a story that shows the struggle of all OFW
I was touched and move by the acting of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards
They made it possible for me to relate with the movie
I'm not a Filipino but I was able to get every piece of the movie because of their wonderful onscreen chemistry
Kudos to the cast and crew
Good job Director Molina
I wouldn't mind to travel again for the part 2 of this movie
It's worth my time and my money
More movies for this duos please
I would always travel with my family to watch their movie onscreen
More movies for Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards please
They've won my heart
Kathryn & Alden seemed too rehearsed and some of their co-actors were really annoying
Save your money and just watch this on netflix or cinema one when it airs

A simple mirror: This is another cheese pinoy movie, but base in real life, that is the point, at the end family is not the principal role, a twisted end, a lot of lacrimogen bomb, good for the family but pinoy is the new korean drama
Great Movie: Its an eye opener to some of the facing problems of OFW
Time Must Start Again  °7
7° °VG ° %: Timing in life is everything; so the adage goes
In Hong Kong, time is GLD
As long as you move you'll live
Over 200,000 Filipinos work in Hong Kong
It's most common to have a 2-yr domestic helper contract as Filipinos are not allowed to do anything else - unless they manage to become a citizen
The cops, inevitably, will come by to check IDs
When Joy sees them, she busts a move and runs
She ends up running right into the handsome bartender and busts another move
She uses him as camouflage to hide from the po-po
Cops rarely bother a couple snogging in the alleyway, afterall
It's done so often in movies you might think that they would start checking, even if a duo is rounding first and headed for second, but it always seems to work
Everyone is within 1° of separation, but it's large enough to support a Filipino radio station
(They have a nifty microeconomic system in place as well
) Joy thinks she got away scott-free only to wake up the next morning to a radio announcement about her
Ethan, the bartender, is looking for Joy so that she can return the kiss that she stole from him
Joy's friends go insane
HLG is about what decent, but poor, people must do to survive: It is all about hard choices
It is also about the nature of love
Joy & Ethan
Ethan + Joy
She resists him, but she can't for long
She's going to be a nurse in Canada
Nt a thing/budkis/pistza/larkaflark/nuffink/jack squat/NATTY
Joy is no wimp
She has a will of iron
She warns Ethan to not get attached
Yet they allow themselves to fall in love
Every day they push the knife in a little deeper
Their story is sweet and these protags are likable
He says he can handle it and he won't get in her way, but as that  approaches the pressure ratchets up
Because, 'when you love, it's all or nothing
If you hold back, then why love it all
' Ethan has a point
'There are questions inside of me that only I can answer,' Joy insists
Joy has goals, a mission, and an ironclad agenda
What does it look like
To Ethan it's: "If you loved me enough you would stay
"  To Joy it's: "If you loved me enough you would want me to go
" Later, Joy asks the universe: "When a woman gives too much of herself, she's stupid, but when she prioritizes herself, she's bad
Is love only expressed through sacrifice
Love can teeter from selfish to selfless
Perhaps love always starts down in the selfish zone, but the more we sincerely love someone, the more selfless we should become
Leaving the shallow end and diving down deeper should elevate our love higher
If not, we must question how much in  we are or how selfish we actually are
A young person should never be expected to throw away h/h future for a relationship, particularly a relatively new one
Joy agonizes over this unexpected timeout from the race she's been running
Either option is valid
Her choice is hers alone
HLG tells young girls that their personal development and future is every bit as important as love
Befitting a modest budget, most of the filming is on the street or in contained spaces
There's a couple of wow shots
They take a day off to go up into the mountains
On a cliff looking down on the city, the buildings are uniformly white
While they look like bad dental work there's also an ethereal beauty to the vista
HLG is a 118 minute, 2019 release that is rated 8
2 on MDL
Overall, this is a well put together production
The writing, directing and acting all blend to make a great product with few flaws
This is a Filipino production and I am looking forward to seeing more of their works
I've seen 2 Hong Kong productions, The Defected-8
2 and Hong Kong West Side Stories(7
Both of them are good but also dark, edgy, sad, and a display of the worst elements of humanity
The group that is the most downtrodden in Hong Kong seems to have a brighter outlook
HLG is well worth the time to get a peek at life in Hong Kong from the view of the hard working, overlooked Filipino community
We have alot to be thankful for

Alden Richards' character, Ethan, is pushy, creepy and problematic
: Ethan will continue sending friend requests even if Joy declined several times already
He will make the radio station talk about Joy in public without her permission
He will use another phone to text Joy anonymously
He will act like a police even if Joy is weeping out of fear
He will squeeze through inside a small room knowing that Joy will be uncomfortable
He will continually send "Need a friend today
" text messages even if Joy has rejected it so many times
'Hello, Love, Goodbye' is at its best when it tells the story of Kathryn Bernardo's character, Joy
In some ways, the film manages to outdo similar mainstream Filipino romance films because of Kathryn Bernardo's stunning performance and the earnest depiction of OFWs
Bernardo, whose acting holds the film together when it was falling apart, effectively evokes a palpable sense of weariness, discontent, and eagerness to alleviate Joy's situation
Actually, I can do without the 'La La Land' love story if the social commentary was strengthened and expounded more
In a similar vein with 'Sunday Beauty Queen,' the film resonates with Filipinos because of its sensible portrayal of what it is like to work abroad in a job you are overqualified in

But how I wish we get movies that transcend this generic romantic stratagem

A story highlighting selfless love and sacrifice: Breathe of freshness on screen, we've been served with a platter of good offering, AR's gentleman antics and KB's toughness and complexity complements each other's character just right, a movie that highlights the life,pain and sufferings of filipino working abroad especially Hongkong an eye opener about the common misconceptions about the life of our modern day heroes the brave ofws

The movie focuses on the life of Joy, a Filipino nurse-graduate who works instead as a DH (Domestic Helper) in Hong Kong
The crux of the film shows how OFWs (Overseas Filipino Worker) live in other countries
For me, the love story between the characters was secondary but it was the right touch to bind things together

A Must Watch Movie
: I highly recommend this movie to everyone
This is not your ordinary rom-com movie that will just give you smile and love
This is a realistic movie where you'll see the life of a Filipino OFW in Hongkong- the sacrifices and dreams for the family
But love will always come at the least expected time
Kathryn Bernardo- never failed me to amaze on her acting skills
She always devote herself into the character and put amazing life onto it
I must say that I'm a fan
Alden Richards on the other hand surprises me on his hotness throughout the whole movie
These two characters made my heart cry and leaving me to re-watch again the movie
That feeling you have when you finish an amazing movie that you don't want it to end
Director Cathy is a genius on her craft
She knows how to perfectly put drama, romance and comedy into a single movie
Everyone must watch this movie
This movie will teach or remind us to- love yourself, love your family, follow your dreams, live your life to the fullest until you have time, true love will set you free, and the list goes on

Overall, not a waste of money
HONEST Review
Why 5
: Lets start with how great Kathryn's acting is
As expected from her The Hows of Us piece
Alden did OK
Wasn't expecting much but it was a solid performance
However his acting reminds me of John Lloyd
But in this movie it's neither
Then again a solid one
Now, the lines
They are trying to squeeze the "hugots" absolutely anywhere they want in the film
Go watch it again, you'll see the same style of focus and switch to subject over and over again
There are many scenes that could've shot with them both in the frame to show their emotions at the same time
It was like Action
And my 11 yr old daughter even agreed how bad the shots are
Compare this with Tadhana, 100 na Tula, Kita Kita, The Day After Valentines, Never Not Love You, and #WalangForever
If you havent seen these, go watch them and thank me later
5 is because of Kathryn
Just wow
: In what may be Cathy Garcia Molina's best movie to date, this movie overcomes the banal and stereotypical nuances pinoy romcoms are known for
In fact the apparent filipino diaspora is the true backdrop of this movie

The ensuing love story merely serves as extravagance but will eventually turn complimentary to the already palatable storyline of Kathryn Bernardo's plight as a struggling domestic helper torn between the choice of staying in Hongkong to be with the man she loves (Alden Richards) and fulfilling her destiny to be a succesful nurse in Canada
Both characters are vibrant and played to a T by the two lead actors
But that stockroom scene is just plain fun and genius
The chemistry between the two characters made apparent by screams of excitement from my neighboring seat as the pair locked eyes for the first time
Forget about the common adequacy pinoy films are usually associated with
We may suck in action and sci-fi movies but we can definitely make quality films in other genres
Like this one
Again, this is not a paid ad

With that expressive face, I was amazed that he made me smile and laugh with those supposedly cheesy lines of the script

Plus he is so manly and handsome

I meant, just their presence adds excitement

All stories are true to life, but hopeful
All stories are aspiring to have a better life and chasing happiness
In order to chase happiness, you should make sacrifices, but making sacrifices is not sad at all
The whole movie is not korean or hollywood, but filipino
There is always room for improvement
But that improvement, we should make movies more like filipino style

January 6, 2024
i really love how they’ve shown the lives of the ofws — their sacrifices, silent battles, and the longing that comes with being miles away from home
one of the main reasons why i chose this as the film subject for my discourse analysis in grade 11
but above all, they’ve shown us a story about choosing yourself — and all that you have to go through to do that
and joy was such a great protagonist for this because how can you love someone so much, and still have to let them go to choose yourself
all her life, she had to put others first before herself, giving up and sacrificing things for people
but when the time came that she finally decided to choose herself, she wasn’t being selfish — she was finally being free
i admire her so much for having the courage to leave, to allow herself to grow and dream
and ethan
it’s a hard pill to swallow, but it’s the truth — the reality that not all the love in the world can save us
joy was never lacking in reminding him that she’s going to leave
she never made false promises, never painted a forever she couldn’t give
it was he who pushed himself into her life, even when she kept on pushing him away

i know that ethan just hoped — it’s not a bad thing — but sometimes, hope blinds us from the truth we already know, making her choose between the dream she’s been working hard for and the love she never expected to find
so yup, joy, tama ka sa sinabi mong, “kung mahal mo ’ko, bakit pinapapili mo ako
at sana, makahanap tayong lahat ng taong hindi tayo papipiliin tulad ni ethan :)
The individual character stories were a lot more compelling than when it was a romance (which felt incredibly frustrating to get through)

I appreciate this movie for showing a glimpse into the life of an OFW working as a domestic helper, and for highlighting the reality that many of them hold degrees that could qualify them for opportunities far beyond the jobs and salaries they’re stuck with
Kathryn nailed her role—her character felt real and easy to sympathize with
Ethan wanted Joy to stay because, for the first time since his breakup with Tanya, he felt like he had purpose again—something he found in helping Joy—and he didn’t want to let that go
the setting of hongkong in this film is so goodd
Joy, a hardworking domestic helper, and Ethan, a charming bartender, fall in love while working overseas in Hong Kong
It's a fairly grounded love story that reminds us that sometimes love means letting go
Kathryn Bernardo, as Joy, carried the film for me as she is forced to choose between love and following her dreams, capturing the quiet resilience of countless Filipinos abroad
We also get to see the emotional toll, economic pressures, and social sacrifices OFWs face living in constant hustle while enduring discrimination, homesickness, and uncertain legal standing
A reminder that behind many OFWs are stories of struggle, strength, and dreams deferred
Overall yeah I liked it I think it's good there's definitely some stronger parts and some weaker parts but the story works and I find both Joy and Ethan likeable by the end and a sweet couple

A heartfelt exploration of love, sacrifice, and personal growth set against the backdrop of Hong Kong’s bustling cityscape
The chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards is undeniable, their performances grounding the emotional core of the film
The story of Joy, an OFW navigating her dreams and a complicated relationship, is both compelling and heartbreaking
It’s a reflection of the sacrifices many Filipinos make for a better future
However, while the romance is touching, the pacing feels a bit uneven at times, and some plot points seem predictable
The portrayal of the struggles of an OFW could have been explored deeper, as some aspects feel overly simplified for a broader audience
Nonetheless, the film leaves you with a powerful message: "That sometimes, you have to let go of love in order to truly find yourself and your own happiness
" It’s a bittersweet journey of realizing that love is not always about holding on, but knowing when to let go and move forward
A solid effort with a lot of emotional resonance, even if it occasionally falls into predictable tropes

This is a good movie
watching this film again after almost 6 years made me think of the changes in opinions on how I see relationships
Joy, a live-in migrant-cum-domestic helper in Hong Kong, prepares to leave for Canada to pursue her dreams when she unexpectedly meets Ethan, and the two fall in love
However, their relationship comes at the risk of their personal goals and aspirations

While it's probably my third watch, this time with an objective, So here are thoughts: I felt some scenes were mixed with the usual pushy theatrics, overly focused shots, and an excessive number of romantic background songs unnecessarily shoved into the film, occasionally straying from authenticity and realism
Overall, the film manages to maintain authenticity for more than three-fourths of its runtime

Hello, Love, Goodbye offers something for everyone—heartbreaking romance, politically tinged drama, and uniquely scenic locations in Hong Kong, encapsulating both the classic three-night, four-day tourist spots and the lesser-known areas

It effectively captures the realism of Hong Kong’s live-in migrant workers, highlighting their struggles with abuse, poor working conditions, the fight for PR, Sunday gatherings of domestic workers, and the depiction of a city that never sleeps
Bernardo and Richards ignite the screen with natural chemistry, speaking volumes through lingering glances and long silences
Every shared moment crackles with quiet intensity, letting emotions simmer and adding profound depth to their connection, with moments of joyful humor in between
The film is lively and, at times, playfully silly, thanks to its ensemble of supporting characters, which helps create a feel-good vibe for the audience

I personally appreciated the character development approach taken by Cathy Garcia-Sampana; the first ten minutes serve as a synopsis of Joy’s character, unfolding family issues—from the rift between Joy’s mother and father to Ethan’s desire to keep his family together
All in all, the film’s emphasis on character building, assisted by sincere backstories and strong performances from the leads, enhances its authenticity
Additionally, the film’s setting—Hong Kong’s hazy skyline, busy crowd, and colorful, grid-like residential blocks—paints a compelling backdrop for a story that leaves audiences hoping for a sequel

they engaged ethan's (alden richards) character into a playboy-turned-humbled archetype - genuinely falling in love with joy (kathryn bernardo), despite the latter's constant disregard to his actions when initially pursuing her
the film provides a definite picture of the fate of their relationship, though cute and sweet, is quite less interesting, honestly
not to mention the soundtrack of the film (charot)
and this is coming from the fact that they also chose to navigate a much essential story: the collective plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW) in Hong Kong
there have been numerous films capturing the stories of overseas workers
this film specifies the struggles in the eyes of domestic helpers in HK
joy is among those who has made sacrifices in an attempt to experience an economic progress
they have to live in a system that limits them as well, yet, for joy, she continues to live beyond the limited lines and risks her life for arrest and deportation

at the center, we get to immerse in the crowds of workers: 'veteran' workers hyping-up 'fresh' workers saying they will get used to it, workers busily arranging packages to send back home, phone calls of longingness and heartbreak, and we even get a glimpse of the tragic situation of joy's mother
kathryn bernardo potrayed the character like her rent is due
ang daming nangyari sa buhay niya with all the struggles, responsibility, pressures, all that continue to burden her, and she carried it all
and nasa punto siguro ako ng buhay ko na naniniwalang parang display lang talaga kung titingnan si ethan (no hate)
but then again, this is direk cathy, and this is a romance-drama film
Here, I realized that love will not force you to choose because love should be the foundation of a relationship
Another thing is that we are capable of becoming more than we think we can
The story beautifully revolves around the life of an OFW, shedding light on aspects often unseen by many—the need for a safe space and a reason to save up
Sometimes, life becomes hard to understand, especially when we decide to choose ourselves, only to meet someone who might also choose us
Like an airplane, it departs with a destination, carrying lessons, and the film portrayed that beautifully

I started December with a classic Filipino movie I hadn't watched
Recently, the sequel was released, so my boyfriend and I wanted to watch the first one first

He loves Joy and would do anything to make her stay, forcing himself to make suggestions
But I admit it feels creepy
Joy's character, on the other hand, was beautifully written
The hardships of being an OFW were fully shown
I teared up when she said goodbye to Annie
The fact that she declined Ethan's offer was also valid and I applaud her for that
Overall, it would've been a 4 star if Ethan wasn't manipulative
I still enjoyed it and would totally recommend <3

Hello, Love, Goodbye comes across as the Philippines’ La La Land but grounded in its culture and story
A romance drama that shows the bitter reality of people trying to chase their dreams in tough situations
Actors Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are sensational and display immaculate chemistry
The realistic story about love/dreams, will touch your heart and soul
As someone who is half Filipino, it was eye opening experience to witness the hardships of my culture
Hello, Love, Goodbye is a great romance drama filled with hard truths and reality
But with added beauty and pain to create a wonderful film
So I saw the sequel to this film Hello, Love, Again currently in theaters first
It was my introduction to Philippines cinema
Once I was informed on twitter that there’s a first film, I decided to check it out
The plot of Hello, Love, Goodbye is pretty clear cut
Set in Hong Kong, a Filipina domestic helper working hard to make the move to Canada meets a Filipino bartender trying to help his family
Even with the truth and circumstances laid out these two are drawn to each other
Leading to a honest portrayal of love, with all the highs and lows that come attached with it
It was refreshing to see a story feature characters who don’t have everything together and are also struggling
Made things feel more genuine and authentic to me
Especially prominent in the brief little joys, no pun intended and adventures they partake in to escape their reality This film did a good job of hitting you hard in the feels
Some might not like how it ended but I did
If you are a dreamer like myself, it made perfect sense
I really have to commend actor Kathryn Bernardo for giving us such a gripping performance as Joy
Her character goes through so much that she has to endure to maintain focus on her dream
Luckily Kathryn Bernardo really gave her best to convey the various emotions of Joy’s situation brilliantly
She had the best performance in the movie
Her co-star Alden Richards matched her incredible acting and energy with his character Ethan
But we can all relate to Ethan because love makes you do strange things
However Alden Richards adds a lot of charm and sincerity to Ethan
Hello, Love, Goodbye is an excellent romance drama from the Philippines
Even though it’s ingrained fully into its culture, it can be easily enjoyed by everyone
For we all have been in similar situations when it comes to relationships, dreams and love
I’ve always maintained that the best romance films aren’t the ones that give you the typical happy ending
This is what makes Hello, Love, Goodbye beautiful
As always, go watch this for yourself

Joy makes the difficult decision to leave Hong Kong for Canada to pursue her dream of becoming a nurse, which puts her and Ethan in a long-distance relationship
As they each live in their respective cities, time and the COVID-19 pandemic take their toll on their relationship
After going their separate ways, fate has again brought them together under different circumstances and as evolved individuals
This is an excellent romantic movie with a good balance of comedy and drama
The story is simple, but the combination of immigration, a global pandemic, and a pinch of cultural humor makes it unique
The story shares how love grows and changes and how individuals must grow and change to survive and thrive
This is a great movie to stream for a unique international romance

I loved this movie
Not only was it a well-written romance film but it also added the harsh reality of the Filipino economy, focusing on how difficult the life of a domestic helper is
Joy and Ethan’s story was well-paced and it didn’t feel forced
They were really a nice match and I really felt the spark between them
Incorporating both of their family struggles with the economy and the dream of having a stable and comfortable life made the film more grounded and relatable
Overall, this film is a must-watch

this movie was pretty solid to me when considering how i was never into these type of movies
ive watched a good amount of filo romance movies and like i said, i was never a big fan
which is why i was surprised when i found myself appreciating this movie for different aspects and executions
first of all, reminds me a lot of la la land (2016) except filipino OFW version
as much as it hurts, i like to treasure those bittersweet or “tragic” love stories because its realistic
i live for the realism; the hope and joy whilst feeling that agony and yearning, bc i think it really shows u how things really are for a lot of relationships and couples; the reality
how it was never just about love and trust, but understanding
understanding your significant other, and how even when you guys do, the ending isnt always going to be “happy”
i think its a common plot and ive def seen it before
i just enjoyed this execution and i liked the mature take on it
this movie felt like an entire leap of maturity for both the characters (esp ethan) and shows the growth of their relationship and of them as people
i also loved their chemistry, alden richards and kathryn bernardo as the main couple
i was honestly surprised bc i grew up watching some of kaths films and thought she never had a romance one without that daniel padilla dude
and i am NOT mad that i was wrong bc i rlly liked alden and kathryn together
they delivered the emotional scenes incredibly and i js loved watching them
i also appreciate another bare minimum feature (that kinda ties into what i was just talking about) but multi dimension
like i said, ive seen the plot been done and its nothing groundbreaking or revolutionary
but this movie specifically also had me looking at both sides, both dimensions, and understanding both
i saw how there wasnt a bad guy nor a good guy, how both were multi dimensional and had their reasons
i just loved how it was very clear and how raw certain scenes were
im giving it only 3 n a half stars tho bc i js still found myself cringing like hell everytime alden richards character was being creepy af and IDK theres js this vibe ab filo movies i cant get over

Hello, Love, Goodbye pulls us into the bustling streets of Hong Kong, where we follow Joy, an OFW working as a domestic helper
Through her story, the film powerfully captures the resilience, sacrifice, and quiet heartbreak of Filipinos abroad
Kathryn Bernardo’s performance is raw and compelling, embodying Joy’s exhaustion, determination, and longing
She dreams of migrating to Canada to create a better life
Alden Richards brings surprising depth as Ethan, Joy’s love interest
His character’s introspective warmth and grounded approach complement Bernardo’s emotional intensity, offering moments of hope and connection amidst the harsh reality they face
While Ethan’s backstory could’ve been explored more, Richards’ growth as an actor shines, lending a layered dynamic to their relationship
The supporting cast enriches the film’s emotional impact, with Maymay Entrata, Kakai Bautista, Joross Gamboa, Jeffrey Tan, and Lovely Abella adding warmth, humor, and camaraderie
Cathy Garcia-Molina delivers her best work yet, handling complex themes with sensitivity
Rewatching it, the film’s painful message resonates even more: love alone, often, cannot make us whole
This is a moving, memorable story of love and sacrifice

I just watched this to prepare for seeing the sequel with my cousin and I was not expecting much when I started it but already from the beginning, it sets up the story beautifully
It captures life accurately as an OFW with Kathryn’s character Joy balancing the hustle and struggle of living there
When she meets Ethan, it’s charming but not overbearing
The build up of their relationship was so natural
I love the scene choices that were made for the montage type of scenes
Then when they do finally get together it feels like a big sigh of relief
Even when it comes to the time that Joy chooses to take the chance to move in Vancouver, their conversation was honest
No unnecessary yelling involved then coming to the conclusion of letting her go for her dreams while still loving each other
It’s a beautiful message to end on
I also loved all the supporting characters
They had a reason and backstory as to what their motives are
The cinematography and story pacing was so good too
Excited to see the sequel tomorrow

With the upcoming release of its sequel, Hello, Love, Again (2024), I figured I’d go ahead and give this film a rewatch in preparation for the new one
I remember not really expecting much from this film, and I was honestly quite surprised by it
It is a fairly solid film that’s well-directed by Cathy Garcia-Sampana
It feels a lot more mature than some romance drama Filipino films, especially in how it tackles some of its themes
It’s also carried by its two main leads, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, who have great chemistry with one another
That said, the story is rather formulaic, and the characters are a little generic
But as a whole, this film right here was still a pretty decent watch
I usually prefer watching western movies rather than Filipino movies because I sometimes think that the plot of Filipino movies, specifically the latest ones, are too cliche
But this film definitely made me change my mind
It’s a great film
Kathryn is an amazing actress and Alden wasn’t so bad as well
This film really depicts the sad reality that several Filipinos must go through due to financial instability
The director of this film did an amazing job capturing the real-life struggles of our OFWs
Aside from that, Kathryn’s character Joy definitely breaks the typical female protagonist stereotypes in romance films where the girl gives up everything just to be with the love of her life
In this film, Joy taught us that sometimes it’s okay to be selfish for once
Especially when you’ve been nothing but selfless all your life
In life, we have to make decisions no matter how painful it gets
Some decisions are necessary in order for us to have a brighter future to look forward to
I admire her character because it shows how much of a strong-willed person she is
Despite Ethan’s attempt to make Joy stay, she knew that this wasn’t the life that she wanted and that she could do so much more
Leaving wasn’t easy for her but she knew that she had to in order to achieve her dreams
Overall, this film is so worth watching

I think this movie wanted to be a lot of things
It wanted to be an OFW story, a love story, and a Filipino story
The ending was a story trying to find a grip most of the time
OFW stories have the same formula, one person jaded by reality, and another who yearns for something more
It works wonders if done well, and the authenticity of this one really makes for an engaging world
I left the movie knowing that I understood the Filipino subculture that occurs overseas compared to movies like "Milan" and "Barcelona"
I would love to see a version of this movie where Joy doesn't have to leave because she's grown attached to the child and the grandmother
And working hard for them is making up for the love she missed out on
But it is an OFW story, and the family she serves will have to have some hostile moment to make us feel sympathetic to her cause
Will give it props that it didn't take the safe-ending - where Ethan and Joy meet somewhere and they'll both have it all
Their decisions have consequences, and I like that they accepted it in the end

Rating: 8
Star Cinema + Cathy Garcia Molina is always a good watch
You can always expext a well produced, well written film that will captivate you from the start up to the end
One of the things I appreciate the most in this movie is how the supporting characters, specifically their friend groups, brought life and entertainment to the movie
While watching, I can't help but think how challenging to produce a Filipino movie abroad
I always notice the crowd looking or recoginizing the actors in the background
It also ironic how a film shot abroad will make you feel that it is really a small world after all, the characters are always on the same places, casually bumping into each other too much
While budget costraints are completely understandable, there is definitely a room for improvement
Overall, this movie did not fall short on giving you a classic romantic Filipino movie experience, giving you the right amount of "kilig" while also touching into social and family issues

i was pulled in from the beginning
this movie really resonated with me having grown up with a filipino immigrant mum and her community of OFW domestic helper friends in singapore

in spite of all the pressure they faced to provide for their families at home, the abuse they may have faced from their employers, they were always so cheerful and somehow had the money to buy me gifts every once in a while
the love and the culture i experienced growing up have shaped me into the person i am today and i will always be grateful

and my heart breaks for these women, including my mum, who gave up on her dream of being a nurse in canada to be in singapore as a retail worker because she met a guy whom she would marry and have me

As part of our lunchtime movie binges, Hello, Love, Goodbye is a "that" romantic drama that explores the complexities of love, ambition, and sacrifice among Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs) in Hong Kong
The film's realistic portrayal of the struggles and dreams of OFWs resonates deeply, while the chemistry between the lead actors, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, is undeniable
The heartfelt performances and emotional depth of the characters elevate the film beyond typical romance tropes, leaving a lasting impact on viewers

with the announcement of “hello, love, again”, it’s was time yet again for me to visit this romcom gold mine
and for this second viewing, i have seemed to appreciate it a half-star more
the operatic, dramatized monologues and back-and-forths between joy and ethan have grown in me

i felt their words better than last time, somehow, and though i understand that these types of writing were manufactured to emit such reactions from the audience, i cannot deny the goosebumps-y tingling sensation i felt during such dramatic scenes
the performances i still find amazing, the dramatic scenes punched hard, the romantic scenes were cheesy but sweet, and the funny side characters were wholesome-ly funny

i did say last time that this was problematic, which if looking at it at one side, it is, but i think it was necessary to further enhance the stakes and to give the characters more reason to go or not to go ahead with their decisions

this problematic element is not in any harmful way being glorified, thus its usage increases the dramatic structure of the story and gives justification to the dramatic choices, thus giving layer to the characters and their inner selves
i’ve also come to appreciate some tiny details
the montage-like cutting was very effective in building the world and the budding relationship
maricel laxa played her short appearances amazingly
the final exchange between the leads was greatly implied like their wedding vows
and surprisingly, i didn’t hate the endless “kung ‘di rin lang ikaw” in the background
reading the logline for the sequel, i really hope they don’t fumble it, they have something special here

You know what
It’s actually pretty good for the most part

I still would’ve preferred a slightly different ending that still retains Joy getting to follow her dreams of moving to Canada, but color me surprised even with the positive reactions, I didn’t hate this
I’m so sorry), it’s a great decision to actually have him learn rather than have men like him win in the story even if they are actually wrong
Script-wise, for one, I am aware that this is a romance film but I ended up being more interested in the OFW subplot
I have merely seen the trailer of Sunday Beauty Queen but parts of this instantly reminded me of that film
Some may say that the film already needed more time dedicated to the romance plot but I wish it was a little more consequential to tie itself to its OFW subplot
There are some good shots with impressive lighting here and there, yet they are never consistent as there are also shots that are too overexposed and poorly lit for my liking

I am aware that the motifs in the score would always be based off of a mainstream song, but having heard Kung 'Di Rin Lang Ikaw even months before this film's initial release (high school tingz), I find it to be a little overplayed at some points
Oh, and louder music doesn't always mean more emotional impact
Still, I guess the film's biggest redeeming point is its direction
Yes, it's a mainstream romance film, but it offers different flavor through its more mature approach
Spotty dialogue aside, the more emotional scenes work well on their own and never feel forced, even if they are a little too on the nose
I did not feel the chemistry of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards at first, but damn it, Kathryn can carry hard
She just knows how to ground her character so well without making it feel superficial
Some people are probably tired of the comedic 'sidekick' best friend(s) of the lead female character but I personally found Kakai Bautista to be hilarious
Not all of her jokes land, but when they do, it's absolutely funny (the Vilma Santos scene probably got the loudest laugh out of me)
And holy fuck, I knew that was Jameson Blake playing Peter

Everything said here may have come across as if the negatives outweight the positives but Hello, Love, Goodbye is thankfully saved by Garcia-Sampana's (no longer Garcia-Molina) honest direction and Bernardo's strong acting
Perhaps its approach to showing the OFW life in Hong Kong can be shallow, but it's a good first step to bringing that story tied with its main romance plot into a mainstream Filipino film
By utilizing the appeal of the two leads from their own different loveteams to tell a new romance story, it gets its point across effectively
Once the credits have rolled, I was relieved that I did not hate it, even if it's not quite my thing
I haven’t heard Ikaw At Ako in so long (high school has officially been very long ago for me) and I had no idea it would play here, nor have I known that I would hear J@$0n M@rv

Watched Hello, Love, Goodbye at SM North EDSA Cinema 6
Its first hour & last 15 minutes tells an interesting, heartening, compelling and high-spirited OFW story fueled with great acting from Kathryn Bernardo
The first hour of Hello Love Goodbye sets up an interesting & heartening plot & main character
Kathryn Bernardo portrays an empowering existential libertarian take of a Pinay OFW torn between her JOY dreams & obligation
Hello Love Goodbye reminds me of Kita KitaHello Love Goodbye could've followed the cinematic style and storytelling structure of Kita Kita to be a great film

Kathryn BernardoAlden Richards is comparable with Alessandra De Rossi  Empoy Marquez#Kathden ~= #AlempoyIf only Direk Sigrid Bernardo be the director instead of Cathy Garcia-MolinaHello Love Goodbye could've been a great, well-made and well-treated film
The film lays out an interesting and compelling plot as well as a Kathryn Bernardo main character as Joy that we would all sympathize and root for
The concept of spiritually living in transit in a strange foreign land working hard to make a desired reality happen one day is the film's conceit that really hits hard to all of us
In this modern, demanding and even depriving world we are living in, we are all racing against time to reach our desired goals in life or else we would never achieve it
This is pretty SMART stuff for a Filipino OFW story

We always watch Filipino films about OFWs where the OFW main character always sacrifices his/her life and personal well-being to fulfill his/her responsibilities to the family he/she left behind in the Philippines
This is a long worn-out story and we had enough of it
Hello Love Goodbye turns the table around

Instead of highlighting the selfless sacrifice of a typical Filipino OFW, the film smartly tackles an examination of a lonely OFW's existence in a foreign land balancing what he/she really likes against what he/she is supposed to do
I believe Hello Love Goodbye opens this paradigm which really hooks my attention and root for the story
Kita Kita almost touches this ingenious examination of OFW but never gets there as Direk Sigrid Bernardo never intends to portray such theme

Direk Cathy Garcia-Molina since "My Perfect You", "The Hows of Us" and "Three Words To Forever" is exploring and digging further her creative mind in coming up with ingeniously joyous Filipino stories while keeping that worn-out and obsolete Star Cinema Filipino family rom-com formula
Hello, Love, Goodbye is Kathryn Bernardo at her BEST so far
Good thing she escapes and breaks off from the tight-bound clutches of her constant leading man, Daniel Padilla
Therefore, Kathryn Bernardo is truly FREE as an actress and as a woman

Without Daniel Padilla at her side, Kathryn Bernardo did not fall down but instead rose higher than what she used to be just as an eye-candy amateur teeny bop damsel of a brute teenage heartthrob debonair

Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in Hello Love Goodbye successfully and convincingly emulates the existential crisis a Filipino OFW has to face as she braves working in transit in a strange foreign land while examining her choices and personal well-being in life
There is a strong libertarian take on Hello Love Goodbye that makes me like the film at first
And Kathryn Bernardo's great acting make that happen loud and bright on the big SM Cinema big screen
Again, this is smart stuff and Kathryn Bernardo as Joy would be one of the most striking Filipino movie characters that I have watched
At least on the film's strong first hour
Alden Richards plays Ethan who is more of a sassy comic relief yet effective MPDG for Kathryn Bernardo as Joy
His character as Ethan started out as a male creep stalking Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in a misogynist distasteful manner that even Senator Risa Hontiveros would never approve of
I guess Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is trying to make a Daniel Padilla out of Alden Richards with Daniel Padilla always bullying or tormenting Kathryn Bernardo for her to love him
Direk Cathy
May Safe Spaces Law na tayo thanks to Senator Risa Hontiveros
But I really DO NOT MIND Alden Richards portraying as a sex-crazy playboy luring Kathryn Bernardo into a one-night stand
I believe his flawed character gives merit to the powerful first hour and what Hello Love Goodbye is supposed to be
But I do wonder if Direk Cathy Garcia Molina inject that sex maniac character flaw for the male MPDG to justify that one-night stand motel scene
Seems Direk Cathy and the Filipino masses are really after Kathryn Bernardo shoving her face to Alden Richard's bare muscular chest
I actually like the unusual pairing of the troubled & serious Kathryn Bernardo with the carefree & hypersexual Alden Richards
This unusual pairing reminds me of Alexandra de Rossi and Empoy Marquez of Kita Kita
The Kathden dynamic in Hello Love Goodbye could have been a more improved, more substantial version of Alempoy in Kita Kita
Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards interacting in Hello Love Goodbye is similar to those sassy Asian (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) teenage romcoms that I get to watch on HBO Red Channel
Only, the Kathden may be something more meaningful than a unusual campy romantic/sexual pairing
The first half of Hello Love Goodbye really sets us up for a promising story that I am eager to watch
Hello Love Goodbye starts well

The film establishes an interesting, heartfelt OFW story, introduces a charismatic, relatable and empowering female Kathryn Bernardo lead character and builds up an uncanny yet endearing relationship between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards
Depriving and ROBBING us of a great story to unravel

From an inspiring, heartfelt and empowering OFW story on the first hour;Hello, Love, Goodbye suddenly drops everything and shifts into a cheesy standard bloated Star Cinema romcom love story with lots of these shit:1
Instant falling-in-love that does not feel earned and 4
Speedy resolutions that does not make a big impact to the hearts and minds of the audience
So Cathy Garcia Molina still adopts her standard Star Cinema family romcom formula into the promising Hello Love Goodbye story even when the film does not really need it
We are DEPRIVED of watching a great story until the end in Hello, Love, Goodbye
The typical Star Cinema family romcom formula that Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is fond to insert is not bad always
This overused family formula does work well for some of the following Cathy Molina's films:1
"You Changed My Life" starring Sarah Geronimo and John Lloyd Cruz2
"My Perfect You" starring Gerald Anderson and Pia Wurtzbach and 3
"The Hows of Us" starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla
This Star Cinema romcom formula which thrills the Filipino masses, unfortunately causes a big void at the 2nd half of the real promising story of Hello Love Goodbye
Including "Hello, Love, Goodbye" as its latest casualty
The audience never gets to watch the REAL, more heartfelt OFW story of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and her libertarian existential adventures with Alden Richards as Ethan
Just like any other typical Star Cinema filmsHello Love Goodbye is so BLOATED
Although she has a charming potential to have an Pinay HK OFW movie of her own
Alden Richards as Ethan's personal existential struggle may not be necessary but should not be emphasized as much as the struggles of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy
Alden and Kathryn's friends should never overstay their welcome to the real story
Maxine Medina is a beautiful yet useless distraction to the movie
The REAL story does not even require for Ethan and Joy to madly fall in love and become sassy sweethearts
Finally, the interesting sub-story of Maricel Laxa as Joy's mother who is forced to marry a foreigner to secure a resident's visa is so not explored further
I assume that Cathy Garcia Molina intend to portray the over-glamorized 2nd hour to be Ethan and Joy's existence in the NOW
But Hello, Love, Goodbye redeemed itself on the last 15 minutes of the film
It is actually the real resolution to the existential OFW crisis that both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are facing

Hello, Love, Goodbye could have worked if its 2nd hour is a more serious, more composed, yet truly heartfelt & intelligently memorable adventures solely between Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and Alden Richards as Ethan
Both would continue to explore their libertarian existence together either as lovers or bffs
As they continue to work their asses off in Hong Kong, they continue to examine their existence, wants, needs, priorities and obligations
And that is where their prospect about love in the world of constant demands and uncertainties take place
All other supporting characters interact at their minimum as the real Hello Love Goodbye story is soley focused on Alden and Kathryn
This is how the movie should be if it were serious enough to be a great movie
I guess Hello Love Goodbye could've worked if it follows the story and cinematic style of Kita Kita
I do wish Cathy Garcia Molina consulted with Sigrid Bernardo on how to make Hello, Love, Goodbye work
Rather than making a great movie which is a worthy follow-up to the great Quezon's Game movie 9/10

As Hello, Love, Goodbye is an exhibition of Kathryn Bernardo at her bestAlden Richards at first plays a convincing & effective uncanny free-spirited character worthy of a companion for Kathryn Bernardo
With this, Alden Richards still performs his best in his previous film, "Imagine You and Me" as Direk Mike Tuveria really puts Alden's talent to good use to make the ALDUB film work somehow
But its strength is its middle part which Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla exhibits that magical romantic feeling artfully around an old house that is really glamorously teasing our emotions
But it didn't damage the story for its mid-scene is awesome
The first half and the last 15 minutes of the film are GOLD in the story

You can look past through the sappy by it being filled with palpable OFW stories and heartfelt moments of almost every character (that scene when Joy sees her Nursing classmate having his honeymoon in HK, then is asked what is she doing there, what a tearjerker)
It has many subplots about family, self-worth, career, and brief encounters that can stand alone, but their sum is a surprising and refreshing experience
(so much better when rewatched)
It’s actually good
There were parts of the plot that would make a better, stand-alone film such as Joy and her mother, the tricks for survival for Filipino DHs in HK, among others
It was understandable that the movie fell for the blockbuster dilemma but in total, I can see how the writing process was thorough, impressive, and a tad frustrating
It's the specificity that I enjoyed the most
There have been many movies about the OFW experience, but this one roots itself in the particulars of the Hong Kong domestic helper
They're women who have made the great sacrifice to be separated from their families for the sake of potential economic prosperity
They are given work, certainly, but they aren't free to seek other work
Joy is pursuing a dream, seeking a life beyond being the absent breadwinner for a family that doesn't feel her suffering

And because she wants more, she can't just stay within the very limited lines of her existence, risking arrest and deportation just to scrape together enough money to find a means to a better existence

In the margins, we see the internalized tragedy of a people convinced that this is somehow an acceptable situation: veteran domestic helpers constantly telling a neophyte that she'll get used to this life, a phone call back home that's about having to extend a contract another two years
And at the center, we learn about Joy's mother, whose tragic situation exemplifies the commodification of the Filipino woman, and the trauma that it brings
The relationship stuff is less specific

Ethan fits into the playboy made good archetype: a lothario who develops real feelings for a girl because she initially rejects him, and then seems to tirelessly pursue her despite her consistent pleas for him to stop
It's cute and stuff, but it feels like a distraction from the genuinely incisive examination of the Hong Kong OFW situation
But none of that erases all the good that the film does

Even as the romance takes the fore, the movie is smart enough to make it all feel burdened by the tragedies inherent to a people who have resigned themselves to the reality of a home that can no longer be their home
Also, Kathryn Bernardo is great in this

Joy is a fully formed character: an industrious young woman who has deferred her dreams under the pretense of a necessary selflessness, struggling under the weight of responsibility all while learning sad truths that will come to shatter her conception of the life she's been pursuing
There's a lot going on there, and Bernardo just takes it all in and makes it work
Good stuff

Hello, Love, Goodbye starts with Joy (played by Kathryn Bernardo) saying something like, ¨In Hongkong we don´t waste time because every second counts and every second we are payed¨

The film works best when it follows this premise- when Joy acts as the ´kayod lang ng kayod´ breadwinner of the family and when she desperately searches for ways to support her dream of flying to Canada to seek a job and follow her passion
A DIFFERENT CATHY GARCIA-MOLINA FILMThis film is envisioned to be like one of the remarkable classic OFW films in the past like ´Dubai´, and ´Milan´
Fortunately, the film doesn´t settle for that vision alone
It raises the story, nuanced to experiences by domestic helpers based in Hong Kong, where it is illegal to take another job aside from being a DH
It also digs deeper, creating a more compelling and informative story about the overseas Filipino workers in Hong Kong
To this end, the film may be given credit for its thorough research

THE MIDDLE STUMBLESIt could have been great if the film lived up to that premise and made that nuanced Hong Kong experience as it`s core, but instead it uses the romantic narrative as a way to effectively communicate with its audience
Just when Ethan comes into the picture, familiar Filipino movie production processes and cliches come into play
THE SLIGHT RESURRECTIONThankfully, all the second part craze undos itself in the film´s last few minutes
Here, the struggles of both Joy and Ethan are discussed and are powerfully put together to give the film a compelling touch, grounded to the themes presented in the film´s opening
The last few minutes of the film however still feels like a long music video
Only this time, it´s disguised as a travelogue
Although, it is in this long sequence where the most delightful shots are shown, it kind of feels just like a long compilation of tourist vlogs rather than an essential part of the story
Another resurrection comes at the film´s last minute
It brilliantly presents the resolution, bringing it to a powerful last shot reminiscent to that of Alfonso Cuaron´s `Roma´, but more explicitly told
THE BEST OF KATHRYNI never thought I would say this, but this is definitely Kathryn´s film
Though this is her most daring and demanding role yet, she perfectly portrays Joy´s desperation, desire, and inherent sadness
This performance is her all-time best and I can, with no doubt say that it is something that should seriously be considered by the country´s award-giving bodies
Alden Richard´s Ethan however feels like a character that was written for Kathryn´s on-screen partner, Daniel Padilla
Despite this, Alden Richards still plays the role with heart
Unlike Kathryn´s role, Ethan is not a dramatically demanding character
INCONSISTENTLY GOODSometimes, Hello, Love, Goodbye struggles to cope up with it´s promising premise
At one point it proudly flaunts it´s technical excellence, and the next thing you see, a drone is randomly used to show a scene where the main characters are running on a rooftop
This film has a lot of potential, in all honesty
Despite this, it still should be regarded as a cinematic achievement as it presents a raw aspect of the difficult life abroad despite being a studio-made film
Cathy Garcia-Molina has revitalized her storytelling voice
A good mix of crowd-pleasing moments and hard-to-swallow truths
The film didn’t pull any punches
It left me gushing and gut-wrenched at the same time
idagdag pa rito ang isang satisfying at hindi toxic na pagresolba sa issue nila sa pelikula

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film I didn't expect to like
I went to the cinema with a passive indifference to pass the time, yet I was utterly blown away once the opening montage scene started
It reminded me of the claustrophobic isolation and weariness of Chungking Express, which also took place in Hong Kong
I thought to myself that it wasn't a bad start at all and it piqued my interest, hoping it manages to be consistently good throughout
And it did
The portrayal of domestic helpers is realistic
It doesn't go all the way to make it a tragic story, to the point of being depressing, as it manages to be hopeful at times with frequent lighthearted moments
I have a soft spot for stories about OFW struggles
Being a child of an OFW, I've witnessed various injustices prevalent in the OFW community
The movie brings to light several of them, and they hit home
Surprisingly, I didn't find the romance corny at all
Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards both come from different well-established love teams, and I was initially skeptical that a chemistry between them wouldn't work
However, they manage to exceed expectations as they bring the best out of each other
Kathryn portrayed the role of Joy convincingly as a struggling domestic helper trying to make ends meet and realize her dreams
Alden portrayed the role of Ethan as your typical playboy, but he manages to bring out enough nuance to an honestly flawed character escaping the ghosts of his past
The cinematography is decent, providing enough satisfactory camera angles to capture the scenic Hong Kong backdrop
The script is pretty standard for a Cathy Garcia-Molina film but sufficiently witty, sappy, and genuine all at once
The score is average but serviceable
Certain scenes could've had more emotional impact and tension without the dramatic music
Despite that, it's not distracting when you have two lead characters pouring their heart out in their respective roles
To conclude, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn't just a typical straightforward romance film for me
It had enough going on in its story to be engaging while being paced well enough
The chemistry is there, and I must admit that the movie touched me in a way that other of its contemporaries haven't
Ultimately what resonated with me most in this particular film is how it addresses love in the most honest and vulnerable way possible
Every subplot is instrumental and significant to the film's conclusion, making a brutal yet optimistic statement that I rarely see in romance stories in general
Very simple and straighforward
It put a spotlight on the hardships of Pinoy OFWs
It’s sometimes heartbreaking but you’ll find beauty in those moments, too
Props to Alden for pulling this one off
I’m so happy to see him in these kinds of projects

And of course, Kathryn

Beyond the romance blossoming between the two leads, this shows the hardships and difficulties of life while living as an OFW (Oversees Filipino Worker) - the limited choices and the sacrifices the characters have to endure
Kathryn Bernardo gives a stellar performance as Joy - and this is possibly her best performance to date
She is clearly supported by her male co-star who reciprocates her performance though Bernardo is the center of the story
Usually it’s the woman who ends up self-sacrificing for love, or the issues of the man are not addressed while giving the couple their happy ending
This played out perfectly - it was sensible and realistic
There was no gimmick, and the direction their relationship headed addressed the situation the leads were in
This is one for the books
Also kudos to the cinematographer and the writer
Kathryn's performance here was quintessential Kathryn, Kathryn on The Hows of Us was really the best I have seen from her
The way the film presented his character and how we got to know him better was very effective

Kathryn really captured it
The film wasn't really the dark, heavy drama-ish film but it made me reflect on the privileges that I have and shouldn't take for granted

So so so film
A young Filipino woman working in Hong Kong meets a young bartender
She's about to complete her contract and go to greener pastures in Canada
And it's by Cathy Garcia-Molina, so seeing her name normally makes me go to the opposite direction, having seen a few of her past films
But this one, to her credit, has a bit more substance
There's a compelling drama here about the plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW's) but blended with the formulaic romantic-dramedy that is her bread and butter
They do the usual "hugot" emotional romantic scene in the end where they telegraph every emotion through overly written emotional speeches each trying to out-romance each other
But it's still a solid drama before that

If there's one thing the movie can really boast about, it's the strength of the acting between its two leads
Kathryn Bernardo acted her heart out in this
You can literally feel the sweat, desperation and exhaustion her character endures in her stint as a domestic helper in Hong Kong
At this point, she proved that she can carry a movie all by herself
Alden Richards also proved here that he came a long way from his pabebe Aldub days
His acting definitely improved and was pretty solid overall
Although I did have a problem with how the relationship started in the first half (Alden really was a straight up stalker, wasn't he

), the movie redeemed itself after, not just with how the relationship was ultimately executed, but the execution of the film's central message of how loving yourself over everything else is not necessarily a selfish thing
There's definite chemistry between the two of them, and given how successful the movie is critically and financially speaking, I'm looking forward to their next movie together
Another thing that I really like is that (without getting into spoilers) the movie could had easily ended in a traditional happy ending
But they chose not to, instead delving more into an ending that is whilst bittersweet, much more grounded and admirable
It made the movie had so much more of an impact at the end (and I already really dug the last ten minutes so that was something)
Hopefully Star Cinema does keep up this surge of quality and care in its films
I mean, it's not a stunning innovation per se, but it's a noticeable improvement in quality (*coughs* Vice Ganda *coughs*)

If there's one thing to be learned from this movie, it's that Filipino audiences do are starting to care on the quality of their local mainstream films, and less on cheap laughs and hollow kilig moments

Hello, Love, Goodbye (Review)CGM's farewell note to cinema is a sincere procedural on the measures of familial, eros and self love
Chungking Express and Before Sunrise, anyone
I kid
This time, blockbuster director CGM challenged herself, or at least that's what I felt and saw
Apart from the word play and tongue in cheek banters we've all grown accustomed to most of her films, this one hits different
From the trailing shots, the hallucinogenic montages and moody shots Ala WKW, this really is quite the departure from the usual Cathy Garcia Molina

And I commend her for that, and obviously giving due props to her (presumably) auteur aspirations, WKW and Linklater, Hello, Love, Goodbye served us feel good familiarity and a bit of philosophy on the power of choice and chance

She meets a charmingly cute bartender Ethan played by Alden Richards during the first night at her new job and the two manage to become friends and obviously boyfriend and girlfriend

true, it’s a marked improvement from the typical rom-coms the studio is famous for but still, despite its spotlight on a subculture of filipino expatriates living as quasi-citizens/residents of hongkong, it is still saddled by the usual storytelling cliches and harrowing contrivances that makes the film less involving and feels a tad bit manufactured

the movie tells the story of ethan and joy who meets in hongkong at a wrong time in their lives — she is trying to get away from hongkong and live her dream in canada while he is trying to reestablish his roots and his relationship with his family in the island after a failed relationship in the US

it’s a good setup but it was not unfortunately sustained when the narrative decided to give more time on cutesy scenes featuring the usual go-to “best friends” that may be permanently engraved at every screenplay that’s greenlit by star cinema bosses

and i observed one very sad thing about the movie: i understand that the intention is good but this movie seems to be telling us that families, at least in the vision of the filmmakers, are the modern-day representation of “talangka filipino mentality” — in this movie, they seem to get, however unintended, in the way of the dreams, ambitions and happiness of the main protagonists even if the portrayal depicts the age-old child sacrificing all for family
disclosure: i saw the brilliant film “the farewell” one day before this film and i may have been unfairly influenced by it into expecting that all films could be just as good
this movie was a quick wake-up call that not all movies are good no matter how well-intentioned they are

HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE REVIEW Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film about a domestic helper in Hong Kong; her name is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo)

In her last four months in Hong Kong, she met a guy named Ethan (Alden Richards) and at first, she is making him go away because she is finding money for the paper works to be submitted to the Canadian Embassy and not a friend or a relationship
But Ethan persevered and Joy falls in love with him
In this film, we can see the conflict in choosing between love or dream, their own conflicts as a character and the hard work and sacrifice of an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker)
First of all, why are there many films coming out in the Philippines about adult rom com
I don’t know why but all of them is a box office hit
It is well and good that they showed the harsh reality of the life of an OFW; as a family of an OFW, it is sad for us
As big as forgetting to fetch their children at school to as little as forgetting to take the trash out
There are a lot of stories happening at once, but they resolved everything at the end
These stories are a gateway to show the main characters’ internal conflict not just between them
COMEDY IS ON POINT
Just as expected with Joross Gamboa
Not too many and not too few, just the right amount of spice
Also, there are too many cliché moments, but it worked out well without me cringing
This is one of the Filipino’s illness when it comes to films; they are too afraid of just letting the visual tell the story
They did not let the audience think instead they laid it all out for us
I hope that they overcome this fear and let the visual tell the story
I’m also glad that they used the original artist’s songs and not just cover it
It sets the mood rather than someone covering it
Lastly, cinematography is meh, okay but I can forgive this one because they shot this entirely in Hong Kong with some parts here in the Philippines
Overall, I give this film a 7/10
Film can be improved by deducting some parts, cut down their lines in half and let the visuals tell the story
Although, acting is on point, I think Star Cinema can squeeze more out of Alden Richards
Cinematography can also be improved by using tripods, stabilizers and a professional drone operator (some aerial shots are jittery)

She meets a boy and romantic dramedy ensues

A surprisingly good but honest Filipino movie about the women who move to Hong Kong to find contract work in the hopes of getting permanent residency, but are unable to fully realize their dreams before then
It's a story about hope, sacrifice, and ultimately finding that little ray of sunshine that can make it all bearable
This is a pretty heavy handed movie that can teach a lot, but also comes with a lot of positivity

I didn't expect to like the movie this much, yet here we are— it deserves all the praise it's been getting
Some dialogues felt a bit cliché and that acting direction in one scene felt too calculated but the two leads were still great, nonetheless
Kath and Alden played their characters with endearing wit and charm, as their oddities make their interactions raw and believable
What I really like about HLG is that as it goes along it feels riveting on a simplistic scale, it becomes expressive of our own feelings
The theme is on the idea of love (almost didn’t work for me), but the direction pulls in the audience through its characters— I am every bit of Ethan and Joy
I work overseas but I have so much to be thankful for that I am not a breadwinner, no responsibilities aside from myself and I have a job that I wanted for myself

BREAKING NEWS: kathryn bernardo reportedly hospitalized due to sever back pain from carrying the whole movie on her back(but really kath was amazing here star magic pls let her branch out)
Once again, we are reminded of the diaspora of Filipinos or OFW's to well off countries such as Hongkong and Canada to look for better paying jobs, no matter what these jobs are
It is sad because of the extreme difficulties encountered by the OFW's
At the same time, I feel thankful that there are jobs and income to support the families back home
Joy's work in Hongkong is hard - her pay is reduced, she gets a part-time job and runs from the Hongkong police because of it
In the middle of this, she sends home money to the Philippines and finds a friend, Ethan
Happiness finds its own source and with Joy, it is in the Central Park where all the "kababayans" provide comfort to one another in the middle of a foreign country with an alienating culture
It is also in Ethan whom she fell in love with
The movie is well directed and masterfully portrays the lives of domestic helpers
Salute to Cathy Garcia-Molina
The script is tight and romantic which clicks with the Filipino audience: "when you talk to strangers, there is no judgement" and " I love you" (witty remark to mean stay away)
Finally, Kathryn Bernardo acts very well, she is the next Bea Alonzo
As for Alden Richards, with his handsome face, he can go places in the film industry
